column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-defense-pakistan-idUSKCN0YA31K	House seeks to tighten restrictions on Pakistan aid	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. lawmakers are looking to use a defense policy bill to increase restrictions on military aid for Pakistan
column2: expressing frustration with what they see as Islamabad's failure to crack down on Afghanistan's militant Haqqani network.The $602 billion National Defense Authorization Act
column3: or NDAA
column4: passed by the House of Representatives late on Wednesday would block $450 million in aid to Islamabad unless it does more to fight the network
column5: which lawmakers see as a major threat to U.S. forces in Afghanistan. The bill requires the Pentagon to certify that Pakistan is conducting military operations to disrupt the Haqqani network
column6: not letting the network use North Waziristan as a safe haven and actively coordinating with Afghanistan's government to fight the network along their border.As they finalized the 2017 version of the annual bill
column7: House members added three amendments related to Pakistan. All passed by unanimous voice vote.One added a fourth requirement to the release of the aid
column8: that the administration certify Pakistan has shown progress in arresting and prosecuting Haqqani network senior leaders and mid-level operatives.

column1: Another required that the Secretary of Defense certify  Pakistan is not using its military or any funds or equipment provided by the United States to persecute minority groups.And a third added a ""sense of Congress"" that Shakil Afridi is an international hero and calls for his immediate release from prison. Afridi is a Pakistani doctor believed to have helped the CIA hunt down Osama bin Laden.
Pakistan sentenced Afridi in 2012 to 33 years in jail on charges of belonging to a militant group
column2: which he denies. That sentence was overturned and Afridi is now awaiting trial on another charge.Pakistan says its courts will decide Afridi's fate
column3: and has angrily criticized U.S. politicians
column4: including Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump
column5: over calls to release him.The House version of the NDAA is not the final version of the legislation. It must be combined with a Senate bill before being sent to the White House for President Barack Obama to sign
column6: or veto.

column1: However
column2: there is also strong criticism of Pakistan in the Senate. This month
column3: Senator Bob Corker used his authority as chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee to bar the use of any U.S. funds for Pakistan to buy American F-16 fighter jets. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Chris Reese)"	['Corker'

NEW YORK/WASHINGTON U.S. lawmakers on Thursday began coalescing around revised bipartisan legislation to help address Puerto Rico's unpayable debt burden
column2: which now threatens a full-blown humanitarian crisis.Released close to midnight on Wednesday
column3: the House Natural Resources Committee's revised bill includes a strong oversight board to direct how and when the island pays its bills and leaves many earlier proposals in place. column5: known as a ""cram-down

column9: we introduced legislation to responsibly address the crisis in Puerto Rico. The revised bill incorporates technical refinements and input from all stakeholders

By Dave McKinney
| CHICAGO

CHICAGO The Illinois Senate on Thursday earmarked $227.2 million for low-income college students whose need-based financial aid has been imperiled by the state's 11-month budget impasse.But Republican Governor Bruce Rauner offered no sign of supporting the measure for Monetary Award Program recipients after members of his party pilloried the funding package as a ""farce"" because it did not identify a specific revenue stream to pay for it.Rauner spokeswoman Catherine Kelley declined to say whether the governor intends to sign or veto the legislation
column2: saying only ""Governor Rauner remains committed to reaching a balanced budget alongside meaningful reforms in a bipartisan manner.""Illinois' public universities and community colleges and the MAP program have only received a fraction of what they had expected from the state since July because Rauner and the Democratic-led legislature have yet to agree on a Fiscal 2016 spending plan.

column1: A stopgap $600 million higher-education funding package enacted by Rauner last month offered some relief
column2: but an early-May effort to appropriate an additional $454 million on top of the April total stalled in the Illinois House of Representatives after passing the Senate.In fiscal 2015
column3: the last year in which Illinois had a full operating budget
column4: the state appropriated $357.1 million to the MAP program. That amount provided for income-based grants of up to $4
column6: 399 students
column7: the Illinois Student Assistance Commission reported.

column1: State Senator Donne Trotter
column2: a Chicago Democrat and the legislation's chief sponsor
column3: said the package would ""ensure that our students can relieve themselves of some of the drama they've been going through this year because of the inaction by this body and the governor"" in passing a budget.But Republicans ripped the plan
column4: with Senator Chapin Rose
column5: a Republican from Mahomet
column6: Ill.
column8: accusing the Senate majority of ""writing a check that it darn well knows cannot be cashed.""

column1: The Senate passed the bill 39-15
column2: with two members voting present - enough to override any potential Rauner veto. But the 68-45 margin during a Tuesday House vote fell three votes short of a veto-proof majority
column3: meaning Rauner could kill the measure if he chose to. (Reporting by Dave McKinney; Editing by James Dalgleish)"	['Rauner']	[]

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-politics-gun-control-idUSKCN0YA2ZV	California Senate passes gun control package	"
By Sharon Bernstein
| SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif.

column1: SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif. The California Senate on Thursday passed a sweeping package of gun control bills that would require background checks for ammunition purchasers
column3: ban possession of high-capacity magazines and establish a firearms violence research center.The bills
column4: whose passage through the Assembly are far from assured
column5: are at the heart of a political duel between Senate leader Kevin de Leon and Lieutenant Governor Gavin Newsom
column6: both Democrats
column7: who are proposing competing plans in advance of key election campaigns.""Gun violence has reached epidemic proportions across our nation
column10: said as he introduced the bills on the Senate floor on Thursday. ""We cannot stand by while our communities suffer from this horrific violence.""The package of eight bills would ban the possession of ammunition magazines holding more than 10 rounds
column11: make stealing a gun a felony
column12: limit the lending of guns among family members
column13: and close a loophole in the state's assault weapons ban.

column1: It is uncertain whether the bills will pass the Assembly
column2: where Republicans and conservative Democrats have blocked some of the same measures in the past
column3: or be signed by Democratic Governor Jerry Brown
column4: who has vetoed some gun control measures.The Senate bills were fast-tracked through the legislature this week
column5: even as state officials are counting signatures and preparing to place on the November ballot a referendum by Newsom that would accomplish many of the same goals.The competing measures are a sore point between the two powerful politicians that could spill into the November election campaign as well as the race to replace Brown in 2018.

column1: De Leon
column2: who said Thursday that Newsom based his ballot initiative on de Leon's own proposals
column3: has asked the lieutenant governor to agree to withdraw his ballot measure should the Senate bills pass.But Newsom
column4: who is running for governor
column5: has refused. His campaign strategist
column6: Dan Newman
column7: said Thursday that the initiative was more comprehensive than the legislative package and should go before voters in the fall.

column1: Newsom is expected to make the gun control initiative a centerpiece of his campaign to replace Brown in 2018
column2: along with a proposed referendum to legalize recreational use of marijuana.De Leon has not endorsed Newsom. He is close to possible Newsom rivals in the governor's race
column3: including former Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa. (Reporting by Sharon Bernstein; Editing by Leslie Adler)"	[]	['guns']

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-puertorico-debt-factbox-idUSKCN0YA2TZ	Factbox: Puerto Rico debt crisis bill keeps oversight board	"
By Daniel Bases and Nick Brown
| NEW YORK/SAN JUAN
NEW YORK/SAN JUAN The U.S. House Natural Resources Committee early on Thursday released long-delayed revised legislation to address Puerto Rico's fiscal crisis
column2: which is threatening to become a full-blown humanitarian disaster.The bill
column3: also known as the Puerto Rico Oversight
column4: Management
column5: and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA)
column6: has two major aims: setting out a framework for restructuring the island's $70 billion in debt and putting the island's financial operations under the control of a federal oversight board.Severe economic decline
column8: lack of financial transparency and management inefficiencies
column10: ""created a fiscal emergency in Puerto Rico
column11: the legislation states.Puerto Rico's next debt payment of $1.9 billion
column12: which its governor has said it cannot pay
column13: is due on July 1. A vote in the House is expected the first week of June.OVERSIGHT BOARD

column1: * A Financial Oversight and Management Board
column2: consisting of seven members appointed by the president of the United States from recommendations provided by the leaders of the U.S. House and Senate. One member is appointed at the sole discretion of the president. Appointments are due by Sept. 30
column3: 2016.* The board has the authority to enforce balanced budgets and government reform if the Puerto Rican government fails to do so
column4: including the sale of government assets
column5: the consolidation of agencies and reduction of workforce.

column1: * The board's aims are to generate management plans that achieve fiscal responsibility
column2: maintain access to capital markets and ensure funding for public services and pensions; and to help facilitate consensual debt restructuring talks between Puerto Rico and its bondholders.* The board will have subpoena power to seek testimony and information. Board members will not be paid a salary.* A fiscal plan should be no less than five years. It can be developed either by the governor
column3: the Oversight Board or both in collaboration.* Neither the governor of Puerto Rico nor the island's  legislature can exercise control over the board or pass laws that would inhibit its functioning.

column1: * The oversight board will dissolve once Puerto Rico has attained adequate and reasonable access to credit markets and achieves four consecutive fiscal years of budgetary compliance without spending more than it earned.CREDIT MARKETS AND DEBT
* The bill adopts certain provisions of U.S. bankruptcy law
column2: including giving Puerto Rico access to a court-sanctioned debt restructuring law
column3: under which it could
column4: in certain circumstances
column5: impose debt cuts without creditors' consent
column6: so-called cram-downs.

column1: * The bill also empowers the oversight board to hold consensual debt restructuring talks
column2: in hopes of reaching  ""collective action compromises"" that do not require cram-down. For a restructuring to be approved under the bill's collective action clause
column3: two-thirds of the outstanding principal amount of the bonds in each pool of debt must vote in favor of it.     * PROMESA does not directly put Puerto Rico
column4: a U.S. territory
column5: under the bankruptcy laws enjoyed by U.S. states. This addresses concerns that actions taken in the commonwealth could bleed over and affect long-standing municipal bankruptcy laws.     * Any prior voluntary debt restructuring agreements will be left intact. This essentially leaves in place the current voluntary restructuring agreement between creditors and PREPA (Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority)    * Certifying a restructuring of debt requires approval by five out of seven members of the oversight board.    * The U.S. government will not pledge its full faith and credit for repaying Puerto Rico's debt. This provision addresses concerns the bill would amount to a financial bailout by Washington. (Reporting By Daniel Bases in New York and Nick Brown in San Juan)"	[]	[]

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-virginia-voters-idUSKCN0YA2XJ	U.S. judge upholds Virginia's voter ID law	"
By Gary Robertson
| RICHMOND
column2: Va.

column1: RICHMOND
column2: Va. A U.S. federal judge on Thursday upheld a 2013 Virginia law requiring prospective voters to show an approved photo identification before they cast their ballots.The state's Democratic Party had challenged the law
column3: signed by former Republican Governor Robert McDonnell
column4: saying it was politically motivated and intended to deter young and minority voters from turning out on Election Day.""The court's mission is to judge not the wisdom of the Virginia voter ID law
column5: but rather its constitutionality
column6: wrote U.S. District Judge Henry Hudson in his decision.While he noted that the measure created an ""inconvenience"" for potential voters who did not have drivers' licenses or other government-issued ID
column7: he said that was not enough to strike it down.""While the merits of this voter identification law
column8: and indeed all aspects of Virginia's voting regime
column10: it remains true that Virginia has created a scheme of laws to accommodate all people in their right to vote

column1: Lawyers representing the state Democratic Party said in a filing that the Republican-dominated state legislature passed the photo ID law ""to stall
column2: if not reverse
column3: the growing success of the Democratic Party in Virginia.""The state argued that ID was necessary to ensure that only registered voters cast ballots and to prevent voter fraud.In 2008
column4: President Barack Obama became the first Democrat to carry Virginia in more than 40 years
column5: in part because of turnout among black
column6: Latino and young voters. Obama carried the state again in 2012.

column1: In the most recent statewide elections
column2: Democrats also swept all top offices: governor
column3: lieutenant governor and attorney general. Moreover
column4: the state's two U.S. senators are both Democrats.Hudson acknowledged that Virginia
column5: a former slave state
column6: has ""an unfortunate history of racial and statutory artifice to hinder black voting.""The ruling comes a month after another federal judge upheld a similar requirement in neighboring North Carolina.

column1: A federal court this week ordered Kansas to register thousands of eligible voters who have been blocked from registering.That ruling resulted from an American Civil Liberties Union lawsuit filed on behalf of Kansas residents who tried to register to vote through the Kansas Department of Motor Vehicles and had been forced to provide additional documentation of citizenship. (Editing by Scott Malone and Tom Brown)"	['Hudson'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-congress-idUSKCN0YA28Z	Senate approves $1.1 billion to fight Zika virus	"
By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON An election-year fight over addressing the spreading Zika virus intensified in the U.S. Congress as the Senate on Thursday approved $1.1 billion in emergency money one day after the House of Representatives voted $622.1 million financed through cuts to existing programs.The two chambers would have to reach agreement on a spending level before they can send it to President Barack Obama
column2: who in February requested $1.9 billion. The White House has called the House measure ""woefully inadequate"" and has threatened to veto it.Democratic Senator Patty Murray of Washington State urged Congress to act quickly
column3: saying
column4: ""This is a public health emergency and Congress should treat it like one."" The Senate will enter negotiations with the House with a strong hand: a bipartisan 68-30 vote in favor of the emergency funds to battle Zika
column5: a virus that has been spreading rapidly through the Americas
column6: with more than 100 confirmed cases in the U.S. state of Florida.

column1: However
column2: the conservative group Heritage Action is lobbying against any Zika funding bill that is not paid for with an equal amount of spending cuts.The Senate's funding was attached to an unrelated transportation and housing appropriations bill that also passed the chamber on Thursday.U.S. health officials have concluded that Zika infections in pregnant women can cause microcephaly
column3: a birth defect marked by small head size that can lead to severe developmental problems in babies. The World Health Organization has said there is strong scientific consensus that Zika can also cause Guillain-Barre
column4: a rare neurological syndrome that causes temporary paralysis in adults.

column1: Conservative Republican Senator Mike Lee of Utah tried unsuccessfully to kill the Senate funding
column2: saying the Obama administration already had enough money to deal with Zika.""What we should not do
column3: however
column4: is allow the Zika virus to be yet another excuse to run up the national debt
column5: Lee said.

column1: But Senator Susan Collins of Maine
column2: a moderate Republican
column3: countered that U.S. debt problems were rooted in the rapid growth in the cost of huge programs such as Social Security and Medicare and not so-called ""discretionary"" spending like on Zika. (Reporting By Richard Cowan; Editing by Alistair Bell
column4: Bernard Orr)"	['Murray'
column5: 'Obama']	[]

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-court-idUSKCN0Y92K5	Trump identifies 11 potential Supreme Court nominees	"
By Ginger Gibson and Lawrence Hurley
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Presumptive Republican U.S. presidential nominee Donald Trump on Wednesday unveiled the names of 11 judges - eight men and three women
column2: all white and all conservative - he would consider
column3: if elected
column4: to replace the late Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court.Six of them are judges who were appointed to federal appeals courts around the country by Republican former President George W. Bush. The other five serve on various state supreme courts.Scalia's replacement could tip the ideological balance of the court
column5: which now is evenly divided with four conservative justices and four liberals. Scalia
column6: who died in February
column7: was one of the court's most conservative justices.""We're going to choose from
column9: Trump said in an interview with Fox News. But Trump said he could deviate from the list and added
column10: ""At a minimum we will keep people within this general realm."" All of Trump's 11 judges are listed as affiliated with the Federalist Society on the influential conservative legal group's website. The organization is known as a breeding ground for conservative legal thinkers.It is unusual for a presidential candidate to release names of potential Supreme Court or Cabinet nominees before winning an election.But Trump is working to assure conservatives in his own party that
column12: he would not appoint a liberal or moderate to the court. Trump allies had encouraged him to announce the names of potential court nominees to allay fears among conservatives wary of a Trump presidency.Trump's list includes: Steven Colloton of Iowa
column13: a judge on the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals; Raymond Gruender of Missouri
column14: also a judge on the 8th Circuit Court of Appeals; and Thomas Hardiman of Pennsylvania
column15: a judge on the 3rd Circuit Court of Appeals.It also includes: Raymond Kethledge of Michigan
column16: a judge on the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals; William Pryor of Alabama
column17: a judge on the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals; and Diane Sykes of Wisconsin
column18: a judge on the 7th Circuit Court of Appeals.

column1: The state supreme court jurists include: Allison Eid of Colorado; Joan Larsen of Michigan; Thomas Lee of Utah; David Stras of Minnesota; and Don Willett of Texas.Democratic President Barack Obama in March named centrist appellate court judge Merrick Garland to fill the vacancy. But the Republican-led Senate has refused to hold confirmation hearings or a vote
column2: insisting that Obama's successor should get to select Scalia's replacement. Trump said in a statement that the 11 judges were ""representative of the kind of constitutional principles I value"" and said he would use the list as a guide for nominating a justice.Willett in the past year has posted several comments on Twitter mocking Trump
column3: even referring to him as ""Darth Trump
column4: a twist on the ""Star Wars"" villain Darth Vader. Willett last June posted about imagining Trump selecting a Supreme Court nominee.""The mind reels. *weeps--can't finish tweet*
column5: Willett wrote
column6: suggesting he was crying at the idea.

column1: Asked to comment on Willett's Twitter remarks
column2: Trump spokeswoman Hope Hicks said
column3: ""Mr. Trump's sole focus is considering the best potential individuals based on their constitutional principles.""SENATOR'S BROTHER

column1: Lee is the brother of Republican Senator Mike Lee of Utah
column2: one of the most conservative members of the U.S. Senate.""I don't know everyone on the list
column3: but those I do know would all be great Supreme Court Justices. Of course
column4: I do believe one name on that list stands head and shoulders above the rest
